maml:description.maml:para: Converts an object to a ForensicTimeline object.

The ConvertTo-ForensicTimeline cmdlet gets a PowerForensic object and formats it as a common ForensicTimeline object.
You can use this cmdlet to make the output consistent with the output of the Invoke-ForensicTimeline cmdlet.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
Object to be converted to a ForensicTimeline object.
Object to be converted to a ForensicTimeline object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-FileRecord 24212 | ConvertTo-ForensicTimeline
Date : 8/22/2013 3:35:48 AM ActivityType : M... Source : MFT SourceType : User : FileName : C:\Windows
otepad.exe Description : [208896] C:\Windows
otepad.exe
Date : 8/22/2013 3:35:49 AM ActivityType : .A.B Source : MFT SourceType : User : FileName : C:\Windows
otepad.exe Description : [208896] C:\Windows
otepad.exe
Date : 9/10/2014 2:45:22 AM ActivityType : ..C. Source : MFT SourceType : User : FileName : C:\Windows
otepad.exe Description : [208896] C:\Windows
otepad.exe

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command uses ConvertTo-ForensicTimeline to convert a FileRecord object to multiple ForensicTimeline objects. The cmdlet creates a ForensicTimeline object for each unique timestamp.

maml:description.maml:para: Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Gets the NTFS Alternate Data Streams on the specified volume.

The Get-ForensicAlternateDataStream cmdlet parses the Master File Table and returns AlternateDataStream objects for files that contain more than one $DATA attribute.
NTFS stores file contents in $DATA attributes. The file system allows a single file to maintain multiple $DATA attributes. When a file has more than one $DATA attribute the additional attributes are referred to as "Alternate Data Streams".

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
The path of a file that should be checked for alternate data streams.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
The path of a file that should be checked for alternate data streams.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows Get-ForensicAlternateDataStream getting all ADS on the C:\ logical volume.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets previously run commands from the Amcache.hve registry hive.

The Get-Amcache cmdlet parses the Amcache.hve registry hive to derive applications that were recently used. If you don't specify a hive path (-HivePath), the cmdlet parses the C:\Windows\AppCompat\Programs\Amcache.hve.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Registry hive to parse.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Registry hive to parse.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows Get-Amcache being run against the default Amcache.hve (C:\Windows\AppCompat\Programs\Amcache.hve)
This is an example of Get-Amcache taking a Amcache.hve as an argument.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets information about all the Master File Table (MFT) file attributes usable in a volume.

The Get-AttrDef cmdlet parses the $AttrDef file on the specified volume and returns information about all MFT file attributes usable in the volume.
By default, the cmdlet parses the $AttrDef file on the C:\ drive. To change the target drive, use the VolumeName parameter or use the Path parameter to specify an exported $AttrDef file.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Path to file to be parsed.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Path to file to be parsed.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows returning the MFT Attribute definitions for the C Volume.
This example shows Get-AttrDef being run against an exported file.

maml:description.maml:para: Determines whether the specified cluster is allocated.

The Get-Bitmap cmdlet parses the $Bitmap file to determine whether or not the specified cluster is allocated.
By default, the cmdlet parses the $Bitmap file on the C:\ drive. To change the target drive, use the VolumeName parameter or use the Path parameter to specify an exported $Bitmap file.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
The cluster number to check for allocation.
Path to file to be parsed.
The cluster number to check for allocation.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
The cluster number to check for allocation.
Path to file to be parsed.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows Get-Bitmap being used to check Cluster 1000's allocation status.
This example shows Get-Bitmap checking cluster 1000 of the exported C:\$Bitmap file.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the Boot Sector (Master Boot Record or Guid Partition Table) for the specified physical drive.

The Get-BootSector cmdlet parses Logical Block Address 0 of the specified physical drive, determines whether the disk is formatted using a Master Boot Record or a Guid Partition Table, and returns a MasterBootRecord or GuidPartitionTable object.
You can also use the AsBytes switch parameter to return the raw bytes of the Boot Sector.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option. Use this cmdlet instead of Get-MasterBootRecord or Get-GuidPartitionTable when the disk's partitioning scheme is unknown.
Specifies the physical drive to investigate. (Ex. \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0)
Specifies that the Guid Partition Table is returned as raw bytes instead of as a custom object.
Specifies the physical drive to investigate. (Ex. \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0)
Specifies that the Guid Partition Table is returned as raw bytes instead of as a custom object.
If you use the AsBytes parameter, Get-ForensicBootSector returns the raw bytes of the boot sector. Otherwise, it returns a MasterBootRecord or GuidPartitionTable object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-BootSector -Path \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0
MBRSignature DiskSignature BootCode PartitionTable ------------ ------------- -------- -------------- Windows 6.1+ 82D4BA7D {51, 192, 142, 208...} {NTFS}

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows Get-MBR being used to return the MBR object from \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-BootSector -Path \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE1
Revision : 0.1 HeaderSize : 92 MyLBA : 1 AlternateLBA : 20971519 FirstUsableLBA : 34 LastUsableLBA : 20971486 DiskGUID : f913e110-0835-4cf1-96c7-380b5db4a42d PartitionEntryLBA : 2 NumberOfPartitionEntries : 128 SizeOfPartitionEntry : 128 PartitionTable : {Microsoft reserved partition, Basic data partition, Basic data partition}

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows Get-BootSector being used to return the GPT object from \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE1.
This example shows how the AsBytes parameter returns the Boot Sector as a byte array.

maml:description.maml:para: Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Gets the events in an event log or in all event logs.

The Get-ForensicEventLog cmdlet parses the specified event Log file and returns an array of EventRecord objects. If you don't specify an event log, Get-ForensicEventLog parses all event logs in the C:\Windows\system32\winevt\Logs directory.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition (Ex. \\.\C:, \\.\HARDDISKVOLUME1, or C).
Specifies the path of the file to be parsed.
Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition (Ex. \\.\C:, \\.\HARDDISKVOLUME1, or C).
Specifies the path of the file to be parsed.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command runs Get-ForensicEventLog to parse all event logs in the C:\windows\system32\winevt\logs\ directory.
This command uses Get-EventLog to parse an exported Application event log

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the file paths that have been typed into the Windows Explorer application.

The Get-ForensicExplorerTypedPath cmdlet parses a user's NTUSER.DAT file to derive the file paths that have been typed into the Windows Explorer application.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Registry hive to parse.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Registry hive to parse.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the URLs typed into Internet Explorer from all user's NTUSER.DAT hives on the C: logical volume.
This command gets the URLs typed into Internet Explorer from the C:\Users\Public\NTUSER.DAT hive.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the file records from the Master File Table of the specified volume.

The Get-ForensicFileRecord cmdlet parses the $MFT file and returns an array of FileRecord entries.
By default, this cmdlet parses the $MFT file on the C:\ drive. To change the target drive, use the VolumeName parameter or use the Path parameter to specify an exported $MFT file.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
The index number of the desired Master File Table entry.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Returns Master File Table Entry as byte array instead of as FileRecord object.
The path of the desired Master File Table entry.
Returns Master File Table Entry as byte array instead of as FileRecord object.
Path to an exported Master File Table.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
The index number of the desired Master File Table entry.
Returns Master File Table Entry as byte array instead of as FileRecord object.
The path of the desired Master File Table entry.
Path to an exported Master File Table.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command uses Get-ForensicFileRecord to return all records from the Master File Table on the default C:\ logical volume.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-ForensicFileRecord -VolumeName C: -Index 0
FullName : C:\$MFT Name : $MFT SequenceNumber : 1 RecordNumber : 0 ParentSequenceNumber : 5 ParentRecordNumber : 5 Directory : False Deleted : False ModifiedTime : 8/13/2015 9:35:13 PM AccessedTime : 8/13/2015 9:35:13 PM ChangedTime : 8/13/2015 9:35:13 PM BornTime : 8/13/2015 9:35:13 PM FNModifiedTime : 8/13/2015 9:35:13 PM FNAccessedTime : 8/13/2015 9:35:13 PM FNChangedTime : 8/13/2015 9:35:13 PM FNBornTime : 8/13/2015 9:35:13 PM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command uses Get-ForensicFileRecord to get the Master File Table record at index 0 on the C:\ logical volume.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-ForensicFileRecord -Path C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe
FullName : C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe Name : cmd.exe SequenceNumber : 1 RecordNumber : 38224 ParentSequenceNumber : 1 ParentRecordNumber : 4061 Directory : False Deleted : False ModifiedTime : 7/10/2015 10:59:58 AM AccessedTime : 7/10/2015 10:59:58 AM ChangedTime : 10/21/2015 2:07:46 PM BornTime : 7/10/2015 10:59:58 AM FNModifiedTime : 8/13/2015 9:35:46 PM FNAccessedTime : 8/13/2015 9:35:46 PM FNChangedTime : 8/13/2015 9:35:46 PM FNBornTime : 8/13/2015 9:35:46 PM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command uses Get-ForensicFileRecord to get the Master File Table record for C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe.
This command uses Get-ForensicFileRecord to get the Master File Table record for C:\Windows\notepad.exe as a byte array.
This command uses Get-ForensicFileRecord to return all Master File Table records from the exported MFT at C:\evidence\MFT.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the MFT Record Index for the specified file.

The Get-ForensicFileRecordIndex cmdlet returns the Master File Table Record Index Number for the specified file.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
The path of the file to return the Master File Table record index for.
The path of the file to return the Master File Table record index for.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command uses Get-ForensicFileRecordIndex to get the Master File Table Record Index for C:\Windows\Notepad.exe.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the specified volume's slack space.

The Get-ForensicFileSlack cmdlet gets the specified volume's slack space as a byte array.
"Slack space" is the difference between the true size of a file's contents and the allocated size of a file on disk.
When NTFS stores data in a file, the data must be allocated in cluster-sized chunks (commonly 4096 bytes), which creates slack space.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
The index number of the file to return slack space for.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
The path of the file to return slack space for.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
The index number of the file to return slack space for.
The path of the file to return slack space for.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command uses Get-ForensicFileSlack to get the slack space from the file that is MFT record index 0 on the C:\ logical volume.
This command uses Get-ForensicFileSlack to return the slack space for Notepad.exe.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the Guid Partition Table for the specified physical drive.

The Get-ForensicGuidPartitionTable cmdlet gets the Guid Partition Table for the specified physical drive.
By default, Get-ForensicGuidPartitionTable returns a GuidPartitionTable object. You can also use the AsBytes switch parameter to return the raw bytes of the Guid Partition Table.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
Specified the physical drive to investigate. (Ex. \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0)
Returns Guid Partition Table as byte array instead of as GuidPartitionTable object.
Specified the physical drive to investigate. (Ex. \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0)
Returns Guid Partition Table as byte array instead of as GuidPartitionTable object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-ForensicGuidPartitionTable -Path \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE1
Revision : 0.1 HeaderSize : 92 MyLBA : 1 AlternateLBA : 20971519 FirstUsableLBA : 34 LastUsableLBA : 20971486 DiskGuid : f913e110-0835-4cf1-96c7-380b5db4a42d PartitionEntryLBA : 2 NumberOfPartitionEntries : 128 SizeOfPartitionEntry : 128 PartitionTable : {Microsoft reserved partition, Basic data partition, Basic data partition}

dev:remarks.maml:para: This is an example of Get-GuidPartitionTable being run against \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE1
This command uses Get-ForensicGuidPartitionTable and its AsBytes parameter to return the GPT as a byte array.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the Master Boot Record for the specified physical drive.

The Get-MasterBootRecord cmdlet gets the Master Boot Record for the specified physical drive and analyzes the MBR's boot code for anomalies.
By default, Get-ForensicMasterBootRecord returns a MasterBootRecord object that has detailed information about the drive's boot code and partition table. You can also use the AsBytes switch parameter to return the raw bytes of the Master Boot Record.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
Returns Master Boot Record as byte array instead of as MasterBootRecord object.
Specified the physical drive to investigate. (Ex. \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0)
Returns Master Boot Record as byte array instead of as MasterBootRecord object.
Returns Master Boot Record as byte array instead of as MasterBootRecord object.
Specified the physical drive to investigate. (Ex. \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0)

dev:remarks.maml:para: This is an example of Get-MasterBootRecord being run against \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0
This command uses the AsBytes parameter of Get-MasterBootRecord to get the MBR as a byte array.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the Master File Table (MFT) slack space for the specified volume.

The Get-ForensicMftSlack cmdlet returns a byte array representing the slack space found in Master File Table (MFT) records.
Each MFT File Record is 1024 bytes long. When a file record does not allocate all 1024 bytes, the remaining bytes are considered "slack." To compute slack space, compare the AllocatedSize and RealSize properties of a FileRecord object.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
The index of the MFT entry to return MFT slack space for.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
The path to the file to return MFT slack space for.
Path to an exported Master File Table.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
The index of the MFT entry to return MFT slack space for.
The path to the file to return MFT slack space for.
Path to an exported Master File Table.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command uses Get-ForensicMftSlack to get slack space from the $MFT file on the C:\ logical volume.
This command uses Get-ForensicMftSlack to get the slack space from the MFT record at index 24212 on the C:\ logical volume.
This command uses Get-ForensicMftSlack to get the slack space on the Cmd.exe MFT record.
This command uses Get-ForensicMftSlack to get the MFT slack space from an exported Master File Table.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a list of networks that the system has previously been connected to.

The Get-ForensicNetworkList cmdlet parses the SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\NetworkList key to derive a list of previously connected networks.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Registry hive to parse.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Registry hive to parse.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command uses Get-ForensicNetworkList to parse the SOFTWARE hive on the C:\ logical volume.
This command uses Get-ForensicNetworkList on an exported SOFTWARE hive.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a list of partition objects on the specified disk.

The Get-ForensicPartitionTable cmdlet gets one or more Partition objects depending on the specified DrivePath.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
Specified the physical drive to investigate. (Ex. \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0)
Specified the physical drive to investigate. (Ex. \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0)

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-ForensicPartitionTable -DrivePath \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0
Bootable SystemID StartSector EndSector -------- -------- ----------- --------- True NTFS 2048 125827072

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all MBR partitions on the \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0 disk.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-ForensicPartitionTable -Path \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE1
PartitionTypeGUID : e3c9e316-0b5c-4db8-817d-f92df00215ae UniquePartitionGUID : ff1a8a47-08f8-43ab-b410-53697f0b2323 StartingLBA : 34 EndingLBA : 65569 Attributes : 0 PartitionName : Microsoft reserved partition
PartitionTypeGUID : ebd0a0a2-b9e5-4433-87c0-68b6b72699c7 UniquePartitionGUID : 6d76ae42-b6c1-4fbe-8d42-20cd366026b4 StartingLBA : 67584 EndingLBA : 2164735 Attributes : 0 PartitionName : Basic data partition
PartitionTypeGUID : ebd0a0a2-b9e5-4433-87c0-68b6b72699c7 UniquePartitionGUID : d6795c3a-8a4d-4fb4-91a0-488812cce027 StartingLBA : 2164736 EndingLBA : 4261887 Attributes : 0 PartitionName : Basic data partition

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all GPT partitions on the \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE1 disk.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the Prefetch objects from the specified volume or file.

The Get-ForensicPrefetch cmdlet parses the binary structure in the specified Prefetch file. If a file is not specified, Get-Prefetch parses all .pf files in the C:\Windows\Prefetch directory.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Use the Windows API to list files within the C:\Windows\Prefetch directory. WARNING: Not forensically sound.
Path to file to be parsed.
Use the Windows API to list files within the C:\Windows\Prefetch directory. WARNING: Not forensically sound.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Use the Windows API to list files within the C:\Windows\Prefetch directory. WARNING: Not forensically sound.
Path to file to be parsed.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets an array of all Prefetch files in the C:\Windows\Prefetch directory.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-ForensicPrefetch -Path C:\Windows\Prefetch\CMD.EXE-89305D47.pf
Version : WINDOWS_8 Name : CMD.EXE Path : \DEVICE\HARDDISKVOLUME1\WINDOWS\SYSTEM32\CMD.EXE PathHash : 89305D47 DependencyCount : 25 PrefetchAccessTime : {4/3/2015 4:29:25 AM, 4/3/2015 4:29:18 AM, 3/31/2015 12:33:17 PM, 3/31/2015 12:22:42 PM...} DeviceCount : 1 RunCount : 40

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command parses the Prefetch file specified by the Path parameter.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the keys of the specified registry hive.

The Get-ForensicRegistryKey cmdlet parses a registry hive and returns the subkeys of the specified key.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
The registry hive to parse.
The key to begin listing subkeys from.
The registry hive to parse.
Recursively list all keys in the specified hive.
The registry hive to parse.
The key to begin listing subkeys from.
Recursively list all keys in the specified hive.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-ForensicRegistryKey -HivePath C:\Windows\system32\config\SOFTWARE -Key Tenable
HivePath : C:\Windows\system32\config\SOFTWARE WriteTime : 8/14/2015 4:18:52 PM NumberOfSubKeys : 0 NumberOfVolatileSubKeys : 0 NumberOfValues : 1 FullName : Tenable\Nessus Name : Nessus Allocated : True

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the subkeys of the HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Tenable key.
This gets all keys in the SAM hive.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the values of the specified registry key.

The Get-ForensicRegistryValue cmdlet parses a registry hive and returns the values of a specified key.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
The registry hive to parse.
The key to list values from.
The specific value to return.
The registry hive to parse.
The key to list values from.
The specific value to return.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the values of the Run key.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-RegistryValue -HivePath C:\Windows\system32\config\SYSTEM -Key ControlSet001\Serivces\Enum -Value NextParentID.72bb93.8
HivePath : C:\Windows\system32\config\SYSTEM Key : Enum DataLength : 4 DataType : REG_DWORD Name : NextParentID.72bb93.8 Allocated : True

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the NextParentID.72bb93.8 value of the HKLM:\SYSTEM\ControlSet001\Services\Enum key.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets previously run commands from the RecentFileCache.bcf file.

The Get-ForensicRecentFileCache cmdlet parses the RecentFileCache.bcf file to derive applications that were recently used. If you don't specify a file path (-Path), the cmdlet parses the C:\Windows\AppCompat\Programs\RecentFileCache.bcf.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Path to RecentFileCache.bcf file to process.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Path to RecentFileCache.bcf file to process.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows Get-ForensicRecentFileCache being run against the default RecentFileCache.bcf (C:\Windows\AppCompat\Programs\RecentFileCache.bcf)
This is an example of Get-ForensicRecentFileCache taking a RecentFileCache.bcf file path as an argument.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets files that have recently been used in Microsoft Office.

The Get-ForensicOfficeFileMru cmdlet parses NTUSER.DAT registry hives to determine what files have recently been used by Microsoft Office applications.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Registry hive to parse.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the scheduled jobs from the specified volume.

The Get-ForensicScheduledJob cmdlet parses the binary structure in the specified ScheduledJob file. If a file is not specified, Get-ForensicScheduledJob parses all .job files in the C:\Windows\Tasks directory.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Path to file to be parsed.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Path to file to be parsed.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example parses the scheduled jobs in the C:\ logical volume.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-ForensicScheduledJob -Path C:\Windows\Tasks\GoogleUpdateTaskMachineUA.job
ProductVersion : Windows8_1 FileVersion : 1 Uuid : e841ef0f-7b64-45da-a8fb-1c3e05196ce1 ErrorRetryCount : 0 ErrorRetryInterval : 0 IdleDeadline : 60 IdleWait : 10 MaximumRuntime : 4294967294 ExitCode : 0 Status : SCHED_S_TASK_READY Flags : RUN_ONLY_IF_DOCKED, KILL_IF_GOING_ON_BATTERIES, DISABLED RunTime : 11/17/2015 8:11:00 PM RunningInstanceCount : 0 ApplicationName : C:\Program Files\Google\Update\GoogleUpdate.exe Parameters : ?/ua /installsource scheduler WorkingDirectory : Author : ?WIN-OL5AKAF1OUJ\Uproot Comment : GKeeps your Google software up to date. If this task is disabled or stopped, your Google software will not be kept up to date, meaning security vulnerabilities that may arise cannot be fixed and features may not work. This task uninstalls itself when there is no Google software using it. StartTime : 10/21/2015 8:11:00 AM

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command parses the scheduled jobs in the C:\Windows\Tasks\GoogleUpdateTaskMachineUA.job file.

The Get-ForensicShellLink cmdlet parses the binary structure in the specified ShellLink (.lnk) file. If you do not specify a file, Get-ShellLink parses all .lnk files in the specified volume.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-ShellLink -Path C:\test\PowerForensics.dll-Help.xml.lnk
Path : PowerForensics.dll-Help.xml.lnk CreationTime : 11/6/2015 8:01:39 PM AccessTime : 11/16/2015 2:45:45 AM WriteTime : 11/17/2015 10:18:59 PM FileSize : 202700 LocalBasePath : C:\test\PowerForensics.dll-Help.xml CommandLineArguments : CommonNetworkRelativeLink :

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command, which runs Get-ForensicShellLink with a single file path, gets only the corresponding ShellLink object.

The Get-ForensicSid cmdlet parses the SAM hive to derive the system's Security Identifier.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

command:example.dev:code:
Get-ForensicSid | Format-List
BinaryLength : 24 AccountDomainSid : S-1-5-21-390730339-1025693957-1587674390 Value : S-1-5-21-390730339-1025693957-1587674390

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a forensic timeline.

The Invoke-ForensicTimeline cmdlet creates a forensic timeline for the selected volume or logical drive. It runs several PowerForensics cmdlets and returns all results as ForensicTimeline objects, instead of objects of different types. The result is a forensic timeline, that is, is a chronology of diagnostic events.
The cmdlets that Invoke-ForensicTimeline runs include: -- Get-ForensicScheduledJob -- Get-ForensicShellLink -- Get-ForensicUsnJrnl -- Get-ForensicEventLog -- Get-ForensicRegistryKey
The cmdlet returns data that includes MFT file record, registry keys, Amcache, event logs, and much more.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the volume or logical partition that Invoke-ForensicTimeline analyzes.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.

Specifies the volume or logical partition that Invoke-ForensicTimeline analyzes.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
You cannot pipe input to this cmdlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a forensic timeline for the C: volume on the local system.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
$t = Invoke-ForensicTimeline -VolumeName D:
PS C:\> $t[0]
Date : 1/1/1999 12:00:00 AM ActivityType : MACB Source : SCHEDULEDJOB SourceType : User : Server01\User01 FileName : C:\Program Files (x86)\Dropbox\Update\DropboxUpdate.exe Description : [PROGRAM EXECUTION] C:\Program Files (x86)\Dropbox\Update\DropboxUpdate.exe executed at 1/1/1999 12:00:00 AM via Scheduled Job

dev:remarks.maml:para:
This example shows the properties of the ForensicTimeline object. Invoke-ForensicTimeline returns the results of the disparate cmdlets in the same object type.
The first command command creates a forensic timeline for the D: volume on the local system and saves the results in the $t variable.
The second command displays the properties of the first object in $t, which was produced by the Get-ForensicScheduledJob cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Invoke-ForensicTimeline -VolumeName \\.\C: | Group-Object -Property Source | Format-Table Count, Name
[ADMIN]: PS C:\ps-test> $r | Group-Object -Property Source | ft Count, Name
Count Name ----- ---- 4 SCHEDULEDJOB 1916 ShellLink 1276123 MFT 293715 USNJRNL 9319 EVENTLOG 423900 REGISTRY

dev:remarks.maml:para:
This command runs Invoke-ForensicTimeline on the C: drive. Then, it groups the objects by the value of their Source property so you can see the cmdlets that were run to produce the data, and it formats the results into a table of Count and Name, so the values of these properties are not truncated.
The output of this command varies based on the system and drive contents.
The command returns the output of Invoke-ForensicTimeline in chronological order to produce a true timeline of the events.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets applications that will autostart due to their inclusion in a "Run" key.

The Get-ForensicRunKey cmdlet parses the SOFTWARE and NTUSER.DAT hives to produce a list of applications that have been added to a "Run" key.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.

Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Registry hive to parse.
Gets the system's timezone.

The Get-ForensicTimezone cmdlet parses the SYSTEM hive or a hive that you specify to derive the system's current timezone.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
Registry hive to parse.
Registry hive to parse.

Get-ForensicTimezone
RegistryTimezone dotNetStandardTimezone dotNetDaylightTimezone IsDaylightSavingTime ---------------- ---------------------- ---------------------- -------------------- Eastern Standard Time Eastern Standard Time Eastern Daylight Time False

Get-Timezone -HivePath C:\evidence\SYSTEM
RegistryTimezone dotNetStandardTimezone dotNetDaylightTimezone IsDaylightSavingTime ---------------- ---------------------- ---------------------- -------------------- Eastern Standard Time Eastern Standard Time Eastern Daylight Time False

maml:description.maml:para: Gets previously run commands from the Shimcache forensic artifact.

The Get-Shimcache cmdlet parses the AppCompatCache (AppCompatibility on XP) registry value to derive applications that were recently used. If you don't specify a hive path (-HivePath), the cmdlet parses the local System hive.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

The Get-ForensicUnallocatedSpace cmdlet parses the $Bitmap file to find clusters that are marked as unallocated (not in use by the file system). Then, the cmdlet returns the unallocated clusters as a byte array.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

The Get-ForensicUserAssist cmdlet parses the NTUSER.DAT registry hive to derive applications that were recently used by a particular user.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the UsnJrnl entries from the specified volume.

The Get-ForensicUsnJrnl cmdlet parses the $UsnJrnl file's $J data stream to return UsnJrnl entries. If you do not specify a Usn (Update Sequence Number), it returns all entries in the $UsnJrnl.
The $UsnJrnl file maintains a record of all file system operations that have occurred. Because the file is circular, entries are overwritten.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
The Update Sequence Number of the record to return.
Path to file to be parsed.
The Update Sequence Number of the record to return.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
The Update Sequence Number of the record to return.
Path to file to be parsed.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the file system operations on the C:\ logical volume.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
$r = Get-ForensicFileRecord C:\temp\helloworld.txt PS C:\> $r.Attribute[0].UpdateSequenceNumber 713538320 PS C:\> Get-ForensicUsnJrnl -Usn $r.Attribute[0].UpdateSequenceNumber
VolumePath : \\.\C: Version : 2.0 RecordNumber : 132245 FileSequenceNumber : 52 ParentFileRecordNumber : 191621 ParentFileSequenceNumber : 59 Usn : 713538320 TimeStamp : 11/17/2015 10:02:56 PM Reason : DATA_EXTEND, FILE_CREATE, CLOSE SourceInfo : 0 SecurityId : 0 FileAttributes : ARCHIVE FileName : helloworld.txt

dev:remarks.maml:para:
This example uses Get-ForensicFileRecord and Get-UsnJrnl to get the UsnJrnl entries in the helloworld.txt file.
The first command gets the file record entries in the helloworld.txt files. The second command gets the USN of the first attribute in the Ntfs.FileRecord object that Get-ForensicFileRecord returns.
The third command uses ForensicUsnJrnl to get the UsnJrnl record for the USN.
shows Get-UsnJrnl being used to get a specific UsnJrnl entry. A file's most recent entry number can be found in its FileRecord's $STANDARD_INFORMATION attribute.
This command get the UsnJrnl record of an exported UsnJrnl file.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets metadata about the specified volume's $UsnJrnl.

The Get-ForensicUsnJrnlInformation cmdlet parses the $UsnJrnl file's $MAX data stream and returns metadata about the UsnJrnl configuration.
By default, this cmdlet parses the $UsnJrnl file on the C:\ drive. To specify a drive, use the VolumeName parameter. To specify an exported $UsnJrnl file, use the Path parameter.
You can also use the AsBytes parameter to get the metadata in byte format.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Returns the $UsnJrnl $Max data stream as byte array instead of as a UsnJrnlDetail object.
Path to file to be parsed.
Returns the $UsnJrnl $Max data stream as byte array instead of as a UsnJrnlDetail object.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Returns the $UsnJrnl $Max data stream as byte array instead of as a UsnJrnlDetail object.
Path to file to be parsed.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets metadata about the $UsnJrnl on the C:\ logical volume.
This command gets metadata about the $UsnJrnl on an exported UsnJrnl file.
This command gets the gets metadata about the $Max data stream as a byte array.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the Volume Boot Record from the specified volume.

The Get-ForensicVolumeBootRecord cmdlet reads the first 512 bytes (first sector) of the Logical Volume, also known as the Volume Boot Record, and parses its data structure to return a VolumeBootRecord object.
By default, this cmdlet parses the $Boot file on the C:\ drive. To specify the target drive, use the VolumeName parameter. To specify an exported $Boot file, use the Path parameter.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Returns Volume Boot Record as byte array instead of as VolumeBootRecord object.
Returns Volume Boot Record as byte array instead of as VolumeBootRecord object.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Returns Volume Boot Record as byte array instead of as VolumeBootRecord object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-ForensicVolumeBootRecord-VolumeName C
Signature : NTFS BytesPerSector : 512 SectorsPerCluster : 8 ReservedSectors : 0 MediaDescriptor : 248 SectorsPerTrack : 63 NumberOfHeads : 255 HiddenSectors : 2048 TotalSectors : 125825023 LCN_MFT : 786432 LCN_MFTMirr : 2 ClustersPerFileRecord : 246 ClustersPerIndexBlock : 1 VolumeSN : E3133CD4233CD4CA Code : {0, 0, 0, 0...}

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the VolumeBootRecord object for the C drive.
This commands get the bytes that represent the Volume Boot Record as a byte array.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets information about the specified volume.

The Get-ForensicVolumeInformation cmdlet parses the $Volume file's $VOLUME_INFORMATION attribute to return the metadata about the specified volume.
By default, the cmdlet parses the $Volume file on the C:\ drive. To specify an alternate target drive, use the -VolumeName parameter. To specify an exported $Volume file, use the -Path parameter.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Path to file to be parsed.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Path to file to be parsed.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the metadata about the C:\ logical volume.
This command gets metadata about an exported volume file, C:\evidence\$Volume.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the name of the specified volume.

The Get-ForensicVolumeName cmdlet parses the $Volume file's $VOLUME_NAME attribute to return the name of the specified volume.
By default, the cmdlet parses the $Volume file on the C:\ drive. To specify an alternate target drive, use the VolumeName parameter. To specify an exported $Volume file, use the Path parameter.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Path to file to be parsed.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Path to file to be parsed.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the name of the C:\ logical volume.
This command gets the name of the volume in C:\evidence\$Volume file, and exported $Volume file.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the search terms that have been searched for using the Windows Search feature.

The Get-ForensicWindowsSearchHistory cmdlet parses a user's NTUSER.DAT file to derive the terms that have been searched for using the Windows Search feature.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a byte-for-byte copy of a file, disk, or partition.

The Invoke-DD cmdlet generates and returns an exact copy of a file, disk, or partition.
Use the Offset (starting point), BlockSize (bytes/operation), and Count (# blocks) parameters to determine the segment of the InFile that is copied.
This cmdlet designed to work just like the popular dd Unix utility. For information about the dd utility, see "dd (Unix)" (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dd_%28Unix%29) in Wikipedia.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.
Specifies the file, disk or partition to be copied, for example \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0, \\.\HARDDISKVOLUME1, or \\.\C:. This parameter is required.

Writes the output to the specified file or directory.
This parameter is optional. But default, Invoke-ForensicDD writes the output to standard ouptut ("stdout"), which is the Windows PowerShell console, but you can use this parameter or redirect the output.
Specifies the starting point in the file for the copy operation as a byte offset. This parameter is required.

Specifies the number of bytes to read/write in each operation. The default value is 512 (1 disc sector).
When reading from a device, such as \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0 or \\.\C:, the value of BlockSize must be divisible by 512.
Specifies the number of blocks that Invoke-ForensicDD reads from the file, disk, or partition. This parameter is required.
Specifies the file, disk or partition to be copied, for example \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0, \\.\HARDDISKVOLUME1, or \\.\C:. This parameter is required.

Writes the output to the specified file or directory.
This parameter is optional. But default, Invoke-ForensicDD writes the output to standard ouptut ("stdout"), which is the Windows PowerShell console, but you can use this parameter or redirect the output.
Specifies the starting point in the file for the copy operation as a byte offset. This parameter is required.

Specifies the number of bytes to read/write in each operation. The default value is 512 (1 disc sector).
When reading from a device, such as \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0 or \\.\C:, the value of BlockSize must be divisible by 512.
Specifies the number of blocks that Invoke-ForensicDD reads from the file, disk, or partition. This parameter is required.
You cannot pipe input to this cmdlet.

dev:remarks.maml:para:
This command copies the first sector of the Master Boot Record of the \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0 disk to the console.
The command uses the default values for OutFile (stdout; the Windows PowerShell console) and BlockSize (512; 1 sector).

This command copies three 1024-size blocks of the specified volume to a file in the C:\Users\Public\Desktop\MBR directory. It begins copying at the second sector (after the 512-byte offset).
It uses the Offset parameter to specify the starting point of the copy operation, the BlockSize parameter to specify the bytes per copy operation, and the Count parameter to specify the number of copy operations.
It also uses the OutFile parameter to specify a location for the output. The default is writing to the Windows PowerShell console (stdout).

maml:description.maml:para: Gets files that have been explicity trusted by users of Microsoft Offfice applications.

The Get-ForensicOfficeFileMru cmdlet parses NTUSER.DAT registry hives to determine what files have been explicitly trusted by users of Microsoft Office applications.
Except as noted, the cmdlets in the PowerForensics module require the permissions of a member of the Administrators group on the computer. To run them, start Windows PowerShell with the 'Run as administrator' option.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Registry hive to parse.

Specifies the name of the volume or logical partition.
Enter the volume name in one of the following formats: \\.\C:, C:, or C.
Registry hive to parse.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows Get-ForensicOfficeTrustRecord parsing all user's NTUSER.DAT hives.
This command uses the HivePath parameter of Get-ForensicOfficeTrustRecord to specify an exported NTUSER.DAT hive to parse.
